data.title: Clarify how to use previewHtml command within documents being previewed
data.body: Testing #5747 Tried to follow the example given in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3676#issuecomment-209953630. The only way I could get a link to be previewed correctly (when being followed from within the preview is the following (externalFileUri is a string): `htmlPreview of the file on disk`. Same for virtual documents. - VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha e77003fd6ca90d944feb572b54fc1d122d91d704 - OS Version: MacOS

data.title: Running scripts\npm.bah install on windows fails
data.body:
- VSCode Version: latest
- OS Version: Windows

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Download the latest code from master
2. `scripts\npm.bat install`

Results in the following:

```
Microsoft Windows [Version 6.3.9600]
(c) 2013 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

C:\Users\Administrator>cd Desktop

C:\Users\Administrator\Desktop>cd vscode

C:\Users\Administrator\Desktop\vscode>scripts\npm.bat install

> Code@1.1.0 preinstall C:\Users\Administrator\Desktop\vscode
> node build/npm/preinstall.js

npm ERR! Windows_NT 6.3.9600
npm ERR! argv "C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\node.exe" "C:\\Program Files\\nodejs\\
node_modules\\npm\\bin\\npm-cli.js" "install"

npm ERR! npm  v2.15.1
```

data.title: projectStatus : [Extension Host] TypeError: Path must be a string. Received undefined
Building windows binary uses electron icon instead of vscode icon
data.body:
- VSCode Version: latest
- OS Version: Windows server 2k12

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run `gulp vscode-win32`
2. The created binary uses the electron icon instead of [the vscode icon](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/resources/win32/code.ico)

data.title: 'Unable to open' error if local relative URL path has query string as part of path
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.0.0 - OS Version: Windows 8.1 Enterprise I received consistent "Error Unable to open '...'" error when trying to Ctrl+click to open URL in locally saved HTML document with valid relative path to other locally saved document IF the file path included query string contents on it (e.g. ?skin=1242&pcl=true ) As soon as end query string was removed VSCode was able to open the file fine. See below for steps to reproduce. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a new empty HTML document on local file system with the following contents: `` `` `` `` `Untitled Document` `` `` `` `` `` 1. Create a new empty HTML document on local file system inside relative 'iframe' sub directory with '2044v01.html' filename to match above example code. Contents of this 2nd HTML file doesn't matter. 2. Open Step 1 HTML file in VSCode editor and try to Ctrl+Click on either IFRAME src= or A href= URLs and VSCode will report a "Unable to open '2044v01.html?skin=1242&pcl=false': File not found (c:\Users\700952470\Documents_Projects\BT MyDonate Appeals__SVN Repository\mdft-html-templates\donate\sa2016\iframe\2044v01.html?skin=1242&pcl=fal.." error message 3. If you however edit the URLs in Step 1 HTML from with Query string 'iframe/2044v01.html?skin=1242&pcl=true' to just 'iframe/2044v01.html' then VSCode will open linked page fine on Ctrl+Click So it appears that current v1.0.0 of VSCode gets confused if there is a query string on filenames and incorrectly says that file can't be opened, even though shown local path is correct and intended file is present in that location. ![error unable to open screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13105488/14857723/3a363e9a-0c95-11e6-994e-184333f86a58.JPG)

data.title: Windows Environment Variables
data.body:
- VSCode Version: latest
- OS Version: Windows

I was looking into how to get user environment variables on Windows and it looks like vscode currently doesnt support that, https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/5b9ec15ce526decc5dd0488339e798f6bcb4ec46/src/vs/base/node/env.ts#L17.  If this is the intention would you be ok if I opened a PR for reading Windows envars or is there another means inside of vscode to get environment variables such as `HOMEDRIVE`, `HOMEPATH`, and `USERPROFILE`?

data.title: Exclude the .svn folder from Find in Files by Default
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a folder with a .svn folder inside in Visual Studio Code 
2. Start Find in Files

Expected Result:

Files in the .svn folder are excluded

Actual Result:

Files in the .svn folder are shown in the search result

I think `.svn/*` should be added to `files.watcherExclude` in default settings

data.title: VS Code window won't get focus after opening a file when VS Code is already running
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: 6.1. Build 7601

**Steps to Reproduce:**
0. _VS Code is **not** running_
1. Focus File Explorer window
2. Open a file (e.g. A.txt) -> _**VS Code window opens on top and gets focus**_
2. Focus another window, e.g. File Explorer
3. Open another file (e.g. B.txt)

**Actual:**
VS Code icon is shining in taskbar, File Explorer window is still on top

**Expected:**
New VS Code window is opened on top and has focus, just like in step 2

**Note:**
_It works as expected when you met these two conditions
1. in User settings_ `"window.openFilesInNewWindow": false`
_2. After opening file A.txt in step 2 above, you minimize the VS Code window._

data.title: Don't take focus after --wait
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0 (1.0.0)
- OS Version: Mac OSX 10.10.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VS Code working on a code base.
2. In a terminal window run `code --wait <filename>`
3. (optionally) On the newly opened window, make changes and save
4. Close the newly opened window with `workbench.action.closeWindow`
5. See that instead of letting focus go back to the terminal window, the focus goes to the previous VS Code window.

Is it possible to not take focus after the `closeWindow`?

data.title: Peek Definition should close after file jump
data.body:
Here's the current behaviour with `Peek Definition` not closing after a file jump.
1. Ctrl-Click to`Go To Definition`. Brings up `Peek Definition` as there are multiple matches.
2. Select the correct source file.
3. Double click to jump to file.
4. `Peek Definition` doesn't close so instead I close it manually by pressing Esc.

![peek_definition](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1297882/14853071/2f3d471e-0c8a-11e6-9155-acdfb38686b2.gif)

I propose that `Peek Definition` is automatically closed when you jump directly to the source file you're peeking at.

data.title: Provide option to change the color of whitespaces
data.body: Please provide an option to change the color (argb) of whitespaces when `editor.renderWhitespace` is enabled. I like the dark background but I can't really see the whitespace markers on it, which are also dark.

data.title: typescript error message is bogus
data.body: The code to show an error isn't using [localise](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/typescript/src/typescriptServiceClient.ts#L216) correctly as it put the parameter as command instead to fmt. This gives a bad error and also fails the message service

data.title: editor options and contrib/
data.body: There are some editor options, like `quickSuggestionDelay`, `formatOnType` which are logically defined by stuff in `contrib` but exposed in the core of the editor. That is a little layer breaker and I wonder if we should use the configuration service instead?

data.title: Make revealing debug console on debug start a configuration
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0-alpha
- OS Version: WInodws10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Launch app.
2. Set configuration for debugging : task.json, launch.json and tsconfig.json.
3. Set "Showoutput" property 'always' to get message in the output window.
4. Start debugging and verify debug window.
6. Now perform build operation with CTRL+Shift+B and verify output window.
7. Start debugging again and verify debug console window.

Actual: Debug console window is not showing up when user start debugging after build.
Expected: Debug console window should be on top when user start debugging.

![outoutwindowissue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/14851037/012047bc-0c32-11e6-8167-ef728e848126.gif)

data.title: Extension API TextEditorEdit.replace only works on primary selection?
Javascript: Open symbol (Ctrl+T) and files.exclude settings
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 8

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open symbol by name (Ctrl+T)
2. It finds stuff in Javascript files that match a "files.exclude" entry in the settings.json

Shouldn't the global symbol search take into account the "files.exclude" list from the settings.json?
It seems this is not the case.

data.title: Watch for auto compilation of typescript file not working well
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.4

Hi,
here is the code of my tasks.json:

{
    // See http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=733558
    // for the documentation about the tasks.json format
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "tsc",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "args": ["-w", "-p", "."],
    "showOutput": "always",
    "isWatching": true,
    "problemMatcher": "$tsc-watch"
}

 But the compilation of ts to js and map is really random. I edit a file, and nothing happens. I must force build, or save file for the compilation to happen. Could it be a bug or a problem with my settings ?.

data.title: Typing relative paths with intelligence

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0 (1.0.0)
- OS Version: OS X 10.11

This is a feature request rather than a issue.

I hope the code intelligence could happen whenever we need to enter a relative path, and a dropdown list shows up to give us some hints for selecting a file to import without looking at the file tree.

There are some scenarios:
- HTML/CSS file: when a HTML src attribute or a CSS background attribute is being set, shows a list of some images relative path
- Node.js file: when we need to require a node module, shows a list of local/installed node.js files relative path

In fact, there's a Sublime plugin named [NodeRequirer](https://github.com/ganemone/NodeRequirer) provides the exact same feature and works very well, but only help writing node.js.

data.title: Additional instance starts in wrong virtual desktop

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.0.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

I'm using desktops.exe from SysInternals to add virtual desktops to Windows 7.
When having an open instance of code in a not active desktop, starting an additional instance will not start on the currently active desktop. 

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open VSCode in desktop 1
2. Switch to desktop 2
3. Start another VSCode instance: `code .`. The new instance starts in desktop 1

data.body:

- OS Version: Windows 10.0.10586 Professional 64bit

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a folder which contain a git project
2. Drag VSCode to screen left side edge, and drag Chrome to right side, let them take half width of screen both
3. Browsing YouTube or some other website :dancers:

This situation occurs **randomly**, and I'm not sure it can be reproduced with the above steps.

Thanks

data.title: VS Code not honoring ComSpec environment variable value
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.0 Alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Regarding #5463
VS Code continues to open the Windows-default Command Prompt, even though my %ComSpec% variable is set to `C:\Program Files\JPSoft\TCCLE14x64\tcc.exe`.

@Tyriar also a heads up that the setting you gave to set PowerShell as the default in #5463 does not work for me.  But the following setting did `"externalTerminal.windowsExec": "powershell"`

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install the TCC/LE cmd replacement
2. Set it as the default in the %COMSPEC% variable
3. Right click a folder in the file explorer and click "Open in Command Prompt"

data.title: How to make contributions to i18n
data.body:
I found translations in i18n folder, but there's a comment said "Do not edit this file. It is machine generated."

So, which is the source file for i18n/*.json?
Or I just change the *.json files then make a PR?
